identificationModule.briefTitle: Subscapularis Repair Augmentation for Total Shoulder Arthroplasty
identificationModule.officialTitle: Augmentation of Subscapularis Repair in Total Shoulder Arthroplasty

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The primary purpose of this research is to compare the images obtained by ultrasound between a standard repair of the subscapularis tissue and after repair with a Biobrace. The secondary purpose is to determine if there are any clinical differences.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: The investigators would like to learn if subscapularis repair augmentation with the Biobrace in total shoulder arthroplasty (reverse and anatomic) will result in sonographic and/or clinical improvements. This will allow for improvements in technique and better outcomes for patients going forward.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: Patients undergoing reverse shoulder arthroplasty will be recruited, consented, \& enrolled. Patient will be randomized to standard repair with sutures versus standard repair with BioBrace augmentation of the repair.

maskingInfo.maskingDescription: The physician performing the ultrasound evaluation will be blinded to which treatment arm.

armGroups.label: BioBrace Augmentation
armGroups.description: During the shoulder replacement surgery (arthroplasty) in order to access the shoulder, the subscapularis is removed from its insertion in your upper arm bone. It is repaired in reverse total shoulder arthroplasty, but is sometimes not as robust as we would like based on tissue quality and other factors. A shoulder arthroplasty is when the ball and socket are replaced with prosthetic components. If randomized to the BioBrace, patient will receive BioBrace augmentation of the standard subscapularis repair.

armGroups.label: Standard Repair with Sutures
armGroups.description: During the shoulder replacement surgery (arthroplasty) in order to access the shoulder, the subscapularis is removed from its insertion in your upper arm bone. It is repaired in reverse total shoulder arthroplasty, but is sometimes not as robust as we would like based on tissue quality and other factors. A shoulder arthroplasty is when the ball and socket are replaced with prosthetic components. If randomized to standard repair, patient will receive the standard repair with sutures.

interventions.name: BioBrace Augmentation
interventions.description: During shoulder replacement surgery, the subscapularis (rotator cuff muscle) is sometimes repaired back again. This will be stitched and augmented with a BioBrace. The Biobrace is a biocomposite scaffold meaning both synthetic and biologic, compared to other traditional implants that are either synthetic or biologic. The stitch in the BioBrace group will be anchored to and reinforced by this material.

interventions.name: Standard Repair with Sutures
interventions.description: During shoulder replacement surgery, the Subscapularis (rotator cuff muscle) is sometimes repaired back again. This is usually repaired with stitches per standard of care treatment.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Difference in continuity of subscapularis tissue on ultrasound
primaryOutcomes.description: Continuity of subscapularis tissue on ultrasound

primaryOutcomes.measure: Difference in thickness of the subscapularis tissue on ultrasound
primaryOutcomes.description: Thickness of subscapularis tissue on ultrasound
Amount of arthritis or wear patterns on shoulder x-Ray

primaryOutcomes.measure: Difference in signs of loosening or wear patterns in shoulder X-Ray
primaryOutcomes.description: Signs of loosening or wear patterns on shoulder x-ray
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 years after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.measure: American Shoulder & Elbow Surgeons Score (ASES) score
secondaryOutcomes.description: is a 100-point scale that consists of two dimensions: pain and activities of daily living. 0 indicates worse shoulder condition and 100 indicates best shoulder condition. The greater the score, the lower the level of shoulder disability
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 years after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Shoulder examination for the difference in Passive Range of Motion
secondaryOutcomes.description: Examining passive range of motion - forward flexion, external rotation, abduction
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 years after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Shoulder examination for the difference in Active Range of Motion
secondaryOutcomes.description: Examining active range of motion - internal rotation up posterior thorax. Strength- Jobes, external rotation, lift-off and belly-press
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 years after surgery

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Total Shoulder Arthroplasty

Exclusion Criteria:

* Vulnerable population
